title: Matthew Chapter 13 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Matthew chapter 13 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Matthew Chapter 13 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Matthew Chapter 13.

questions.question: Where did Jesus sit when he went out of the house on that day?
options: By the sea side
On a mountain
In a synagogue
In a garden
questions.correctAnswer: By the sea side
questions.explanation: Matthew 13:1 states that Jesus went out of the house and sat by the sea side.

questions.question: What did Jesus do when great multitudes gathered together unto him?
options: He went into a ship and sat
He climbed a tree
He walked among the crowd
He entered a house
questions.correctAnswer: He went into a ship and sat
questions.explanation: According to Matthew 13:2, Jesus went into a ship and sat while the multitude stood on the shore.

questions.question: What type of teaching method did Jesus use to speak to the multitudes?
options: Parables
Direct commands
Songs
Poems
questions.correctAnswer: Parables
questions.explanation: Matthew 13:3 tells us that Jesus spake many things unto them in parables.

questions.question: What happened to the seeds that fell by the way side?
options: The fowls devoured them
They grew into strong plants
They withered away
They were choked by thorns
questions.correctAnswer: The fowls devoured them
questions.explanation: Matthew 13:4 explains that seeds falling by the way side were devoured by the fowls.

questions.question: Why did the seeds that fell on stony places wither away?
options: Because they had no root
Because they were eaten by birds
Because they were choked by thorns
Because they were planted in bad soil
questions.correctAnswer: Because they had no root
questions.explanation: Verses Matthew 13:5-6 describe that seeds on stony places sprung up quickly but withered because they had no root.

questions.question: What choked the seeds that fell among thorns?
options: Thorns
Rocks
Water
Sunlight
questions.correctAnswer: Thorns
questions.explanation: Matthew 13:7 states that the thorns sprang up and choked the seeds.

questions.question: What happened to the seeds that fell into good ground?
options: They brought forth fruit, some an hundredfold, some sixtyfold, some thirtyfold
They were eaten by birds
They withered away
They were choked by thorns
questions.correctAnswer: They brought forth fruit, some an hundredfold, some sixtyfold, some thirtyfold
questions.explanation: Matthew 13:8 says seeds in good ground brought forth fruit in varying measures.

questions.question: Why did Jesus say he spoke to the people in parables?
options: Because seeing they see not, and hearing they hear not
Because they understood everything
Because it was easier to teach
Because he wanted to confuse them
questions.correctAnswer: Because seeing they see not, and hearing they hear not
questions.explanation: Matthew 13:13 explains Jesus spoke in parables because people seeing see not and hearing hear not, nor understand.

questions.question: Who is compared to the one who sowed good seed in the field?
options: The Son of man
The devil
The angels
The disciples
questions.correctAnswer: The Son of man
questions.explanation: Matthew 13:37 identifies the sower of good seed as the Son of man.

questions.question: What is the field symbolic of in the parable of the tares?
options: The world
The church
The synagogue
The kingdom of heaven
questions.correctAnswer: The world
questions.explanation: Matthew 13:38 states that the field is the world.

questions.question: True or False: The enemy who sowed the tares among the wheat is the devil.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Matthew 13:39 clearly states the enemy that sowed the tares is the devil.

questions.question: True or False: The harvest in the parable represents the end of the world.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: According to Matthew 13:39, the harvest is the end of the world.

questions.question: True or False: Jesus did many mighty works in his own country because of their great faith.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Matthew 13:58 states Jesus did not many mighty works there because of their unbelief.

questions.question: Complete this verse from Matthew 13:44: 'Again, the kingdom of heaven is like unto treasure hid in a ______; the which when a man hath found, he hideth, and for joy thereof goeth and selleth all that he hath, and buyeth that field.'
options: field
house
garden
market
questions.correctAnswer: field
questions.explanation: Matthew 13:44 says the kingdom of heaven is like treasure hid in a field.

questions.question: What did the merchant man do when he found a pearl of great price?
options: He went and sold all that he had and bought it
He ignored it
He gave it away
He hid it in a box
questions.correctAnswer: He went and sold all that he had and bought it
questions.explanation: Matthew 13:46 tells that the merchant sold all he had and bought the pearl of great price.

medium.title: Matthew Chapter 13 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Matthew Chapter 13 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with understanding why Jesus often taught in parables. Based on Matthew 13, what biblical truth would you share about the purpose of parables?
options: Parables reveal the mysteries of the kingdom of heaven to those given understanding
Parables were meant to confuse the listeners
Parables were used only to entertain the crowd
Parables were a way to avoid direct teaching
questions.correctAnswer: Parables reveal the mysteries of the kingdom of heaven to those given understanding
questions.explanation: Matthew 13:10-11 explains that Jesus spoke in parables because knowledge of the kingdom's mysteries was given to the disciples but not to others, and verses 13-15 show the spiritual blindness of many.

questions.question: How does the Parable of the Sower in Matthew 13 teach us about perseverance in faith despite challenges?
options: Those who receive the word on stony places endure for a while but fall away under persecution
Faith should be tested by persecution to prove its worth
One should avoid trials to keep faith strong
Only those without trials are true believers
questions.correctAnswer: Those who receive the word on stony places endure for a while but fall away under persecution
questions.explanation: Matthew 13:20-21 describes the seed on stony ground as those who receive the word joyfully but have no root and quickly fall away when troubles come, highlighting the need to deepen faith to persevere.

questions.question: A believer is distracted by worldly cares and wealth, hindering their spiritual growth. What does Matthew 13 teach about this condition?
options: The cares of this world and deceitfulness of riches choke the word, making one unfruitful
Wealth is a sign of God's blessing and should be pursued
Worldly cares have no impact on spiritual life
Riches guarantee a fruitful Christian life
questions.correctAnswer: The cares of this world and deceitfulness of riches choke the word, making one unfruitful
questions.explanation: Matthew 13:22 teaches that those who hear the word but allow worldly concerns and riches to dominate become unfruitful, emphasizing the need for focus and stewardship.

questions.question: What practical lesson about faith and fruitfulness does the Parable of the Sower and the good ground teach us?
options: Hearing and understanding God's word leads to bearing fruit in varying measures
Only perfect people bear fruit
Fruitfulness depends on human effort alone
All believers will bear the same amount of fruit
questions.correctAnswer: Hearing and understanding God's word leads to bearing fruit in varying measures
questions.explanation: Matthew 13:23 states that the seed sown on good ground represents those who hear, understand, and bear fruit, showing that obedience and comprehension lead to spiritual growth.

questions.question: According to Matthew 13, how should believers respond to the presence of evil and temptation in the world until the final judgment?
options: Let both good and evil coexist until the harvest, the time of judgment
Remove all evil immediately by force
Ignore evil as it will go away on its own
Avoid the world entirely
questions.correctAnswer: Let both good and evil coexist until the harvest, the time of judgment
questions.explanation: Matthew 13:29-30 explains that the wheat and tares grow together until the harvest, symbolizing the coexistence of good and evil until God's final judgment.

questions.question: How does the Parable of the Mustard Seed in Matthew 13 encourage believers about the growth of God's kingdom?
options: Small beginnings can grow into something great and sheltering
Only large efforts lead to growth
Kingdom growth is instant and visible
Faith must be large from the start
questions.correctAnswer: Small beginnings can grow into something great and sheltering
questions.explanation: Matthew 13:31-32 shows the mustard seed as the smallest seed growing into the largest herb, symbolizing how small faith or efforts can lead to great spiritual impact.

questions.question: What does the Parable of the Leaven teach about the influence of God's kingdom in a believer's life?
options: God's kingdom works quietly and permeates the whole person gradually
Faith is only external and visible
Kingdom influence is sudden and overwhelming
Leaven represents sin that corrupts
questions.correctAnswer: God's kingdom works quietly and permeates the whole person gradually
questions.explanation: Matthew 13:33 compares the kingdom of heaven to leaven that a woman hid in meal until it permeated all, teaching gradual inward transformation through God's work.

questions.question: A Christian is discouraged because they have not seen or heard miraculous signs like the prophets of old. What encouragement does Matthew 13 offer?
options: Blessed are your eyes and ears for seeing and hearing the kingdom's truths
They have missed out on God's blessings
Miracles are required to prove faith
Only prophets truly understand God's kingdom
questions.correctAnswer: Blessed are your eyes and ears for seeing and hearing the kingdom's truths
questions.explanation: Matthew 13:16-17 encourages believers that they are blessed to witness what many prophets desired but did not see or hear, affirming the privilege of the Gospel message.

questions.question: True or False: According to Matthew 13, Jesus performed many mighty works in his hometown despite their unbelief.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Matthew 13:58 states that Jesus did not do many mighty works in his hometown because of their unbelief, showing the impact of faith on receiving God's power.

questions.question: True or False: The Parable of the Net teaches that at the end of the age, angels will separate the wicked from the righteous.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Matthew 13:47-49 explains that the kingdom of heaven is like a net gathering all kinds of fish, which are then separated by angels at the end of the world, symbolizing final judgment.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: In the Parable of the Tares, the 'field' represents the _____, and the 'good seed' are the children of the kingdom.
options: world
church
heaven
earth
questions.correctAnswer: world
questions.explanation: Matthew 13:38 clarifies that the field represents the world, where the good seed (children of the kingdom) and tares (children of the wicked) coexist until the final harvest.

questions.question: How does Matthew 13 teach about the importance of having 'ears to hear' in spiritual growth?
options: Spiritual understanding requires a willing heart and attentive hearing
Hearing is only physical and not related to faith
All people automatically understand God's word
Hearing is unnecessary if one reads the Bible
questions.correctAnswer: Spiritual understanding requires a willing heart and attentive hearing
questions.explanation: Verses like Matthew 13:9 and 13:43 emphasize 'Who hath ears to hear, let him hear,' highlighting the need for spiritual receptivity to understand God's message.

questions.question: A believer is worried about sharing the Gospel because of rejection. What does the Parable of the Wheat and Tares teach about dealing with opposition?
options: Good and evil will coexist until God’s final judgment, so believers must continue sowing faithfully
Believers should stop sharing the Gospel when rejected
Only perfect conditions allow for fruitful evangelism
Opposition means God has rejected the believer
questions.correctAnswer: Good and evil will coexist until God’s final judgment, so believers must continue sowing faithfully
questions.explanation: Matthew 13:24-30 teaches that both wheat and tares grow together until the harvest, indicating that believers must persist despite opposition until God’s final judgment.

questions.question: What does Matthew 13 say about the attitude of believers toward God's kingdom compared to earthly possessions?
options: Believers should joyfully give up all to gain the kingdom, like the man who sold all to buy the field or pearl
Earthly wealth is the ultimate goal
Kingdom values are secondary to possessions
Moderation in giving is discouraged
questions.correctAnswer: Believers should joyfully give up all to gain the kingdom, like the man who sold all to buy the field or pearl
questions.explanation: Matthew 13:44-46 illustrates the kingdom of heaven as treasure and pearl of great price, motivating believers to prioritize it above all worldly possessions.

questions.question: How does Matthew 13 instruct believers to handle spiritual knowledge and teaching within the community?
options: Every scribe instructed in the kingdom is like a householder bringing forth new and old treasures
Spiritual knowledge is only for leaders and not to be shared
Teaching should be limited to old traditions only
New teachings should replace old ones entirely
questions.correctAnswer: Every scribe instructed in the kingdom is like a householder bringing forth new and old treasures
questions.explanation: Matthew 13:52 states that those taught in the kingdom are like householders who bring out both new and old treasures, emphasizing balanced teaching and stewardship of knowledge.

hard.title: Matthew Chapter 13 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Matthew Chapter 13.

questions.question: In the parable of the sower, what is the meaning of the seed that fell on stony places according to Matthew 13?
options: One who hears the word and immediately receives it with joy but has no root
One who hears the word but does not understand it
One who is choked by the cares of the world
One who bears fruit a hundredfold
questions.correctAnswer: One who hears the word and immediately receives it with joy but has no root
questions.explanation: Matthew 13:20-21 explains that the seed on stony places represents one who hears the word, receives it joyfully, but has no root and quickly falls away.

questions.question: Which Old Testament prophet's prophecy is cited in Matthew 13 to explain why people hear but do not understand Jesus' parables?
options: Isaiah
Jeremiah
Ezekiel
Daniel
questions.correctAnswer: Isaiah
questions.explanation: Matthew 13:14 explicitly references the prophecy of Esaias (Isaiah) to explain the spiritual dullness of the people hearing the parables.

questions.question: What is symbolized by the mustard seed in the parable Jesus tells in Matthew 13?
options: The kingdom of heaven growing from the smallest beginnings to great influence
The initial rejection of the kingdom by many
The division between wheat and tares
The hidden treasure in a field
questions.correctAnswer: The kingdom of heaven growing from the smallest beginnings to great influence
questions.explanation: Matthew 13:31-32 describes the mustard seed as the smallest seed that grows into the greatest among herbs, symbolizing the expansive growth of God's kingdom.

questions.question: In Matthew 13, who are identified as the 'children of the wicked one' in the parable of the tares?
options: The tares sown by the enemy
The disciples of Jesus
The children of the kingdom
The angels
questions.correctAnswer: The tares sown by the enemy
questions.explanation: Matthew 13:38 clarifies that the tares represent the children of the wicked one, sown by the enemy, who is the devil.

questions.question: Why does Jesus say he speaks to the multitudes in parables according to Matthew 13?
options: Because seeing they see not, and hearing they hear not, nor understand
Because parables are easier to remember
Because the disciples requested it
Because the Pharisees demanded it
questions.correctAnswer: Because seeing they see not, and hearing they hear not, nor understand
questions.explanation: Matthew 13:13 explains that Jesus uses parables because many hear and see but do not comprehend, fulfilling Isaiah’s prophecy.

questions.question: What is the significance of the phrase 'Who hath ears to hear, let him hear' repeated in Matthew 13?
options: It emphasizes the need for spiritual perceptiveness
It is a call to the Pharisees to listen
It indicates the end of the parable
It is a common greeting in Jesus' time
questions.correctAnswer: It emphasizes the need for spiritual perceptiveness
questions.explanation: Repeated in Matthew 13:9 and 43, this phrase calls for attentive listening and understanding beyond the literal hearing.

questions.question: According to Matthew 13, what will happen at the end of the world concerning the wheat and tares?
options: The tares will be gathered and burned, the wheat gathered into the barn
Both wheat and tares will be destroyed
The wheat will be burned and the tares saved
The wheat will be separated and discarded
questions.correctAnswer: The tares will be gathered and burned, the wheat gathered into the barn
questions.explanation: Matthew 13:40-42 describes the final judgment where the tares are burned and the wheat is gathered into God's barn.

questions.question: True or False: In Matthew 13, Jesus explains that the kingdom of heaven is like leaven hidden in three measures of meal.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Matthew 13:33 records Jesus' parable comparing the kingdom of heaven to leaven hidden in meal, which permeates the whole.

questions.question: What is the role of the angels mentioned in the parable of the tares in Matthew 13?
options: They are the reapers who gather tares and wheat at the end of the age
They sow the good seed
They teach the parables to the people
They resist the kingdom of heaven
questions.correctAnswer: They are the reapers who gather tares and wheat at the end of the age
questions.explanation: Matthew 13:39 and 41 identify angels as the reapers who separate the righteous from the wicked at the end of the world.

questions.question: In Matthew 13, what cultural agricultural practice is illustrated by the parable of the sower?
options: Sowing seed in various types of soil to indicate receptivity
Harvesting crops with sickles
Threshing wheat in a barn
Tilling the ground with oxen
questions.correctAnswer: Sowing seed in various types of soil to indicate receptivity
questions.explanation: The parable (Matthew 13:3-8) uses the common practice of sowing seed on different ground types to illustrate responses to God's word.

questions.question: Which literary device is predominantly used throughout Matthew 13 to convey spiritual truths?
options: Parable
Allegory
Prophecy
Psalm
questions.correctAnswer: Parable
questions.explanation: Matthew 13:34 states that Jesus spoke all these things to the multitude in parables, using storytelling for teaching.

questions.question: How does the parable of the treasure hidden in a field (Matthew 13) typologically relate to the concept of salvation?
options: It illustrates the priceless value of the kingdom of heaven worth sacrificing all to obtain
It warns against greed and hoarding wealth
It teaches about agricultural land ownership
It describes the future judgment
questions.correctAnswer: It illustrates the priceless value of the kingdom of heaven worth sacrificing all to obtain
questions.explanation: Matthew 13:44 shows the man who sells all he has to buy the field where treasure is hidden, typifying the supreme value of God's kingdom.

questions.question: What is the significance of Jesus being called 'the carpenter's son' in Matthew 13:55 within the historical context?
options: It reflects Jesus' humble origins and local skepticism about his authority
It indicates he was a wealthy artisan
It means he was a prophet from Nazareth
It shows he was educated in the synagogue
questions.correctAnswer: It reflects Jesus' humble origins and local skepticism about his authority
questions.explanation: Matthew 13:55-57 reveal that Jesus' neighbors questioned his wisdom and works because of his ordinary family background, highlighting social barriers to acceptance.

questions.question: According to Matthew 13, what is the 'field' in the parable of the tares a metaphor for?
options: The world
The synagogue
The kingdom of heaven
The church
questions.correctAnswer: The world
questions.explanation: Matthew 13:38 states the field represents the world in which both good and evil children coexist until judgment.

questions.question: What does Jesus mean by saying 'every scribe which is instructed unto the kingdom of heaven is like unto a man that is an householder' in Matthew 13?
options: Such a scribe brings forth treasure both new and old from his knowledge
Such a scribe only teaches old traditions
Such a scribe is a wealthy landowner
Such a scribe rejects the kingdom of heaven
questions.correctAnswer: Such a scribe brings forth treasure both new and old from his knowledge
questions.explanation: Matthew 13:52 portrays a scribe trained in the kingdom as one who shares both new insights and familiar truths, enriching others.

theological.title: Matthew Chapter 13 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Matthew Chapter 13 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: In Matthew 13, the parable of the sower illustrates different responses to the word of the kingdom. What does the seed that falls on good ground represent?
options: Those who hear and understand the word, producing fruit
Those who hear but quickly lose faith under persecution
Those who reject the word because of worldly distractions
Those who never truly hear the word
questions.correctAnswer: Those who hear and understand the word, producing fruit
questions.explanation: Matthew 13:23 explains that the seed sown on good ground represents those who hear the word, understand it, and bear fruit, some a hundredfold, some sixty, some thirty. This reflects genuine faith producing spiritual fruit (Psalm 1:3; John 15:5; Galatians 5:22-23; James 1:22).

questions.question: Why does Jesus say He speaks to the people in parables according to Matthew 13?
options: Because it is given to the disciples to know the mysteries but not to others
To confuse the people intentionally
To make the message more entertaining
To avoid giving direct answers to the Pharisees
questions.correctAnswer: Because it is given to the disciples to know the mysteries but not to others
questions.explanation: In Matthew 13:11-13, Jesus explains that parables are used because the knowledge of the kingdom's mysteries is given to the disciples but not to others. This fulfills Isaiah's prophecy about seeing and hearing without understanding (Isaiah 6:9-10; Romans 11:8; John 12:40; Acts 28:26-27).

questions.question: According to Matthew 13, who is the sower in the parable of the tares?
options: The Son of Man
The devil
The angels
The disciples
questions.correctAnswer: The Son of Man
questions.explanation: Matthew 13:37 identifies the sower as the Son of Man, who sows the good seed representing the children of the kingdom. This highlights Christ’s role in salvation and judgment (John 1:29; Hebrews 4:14; Revelation 1:13; Daniel 7:13).

questions.question: What is the significance of the enemy sowing tares among the wheat in the parable?
options: The enemy represents the devil sowing wickedness among believers
It symbolizes a natural disaster
It illustrates the mixing of Jews and Gentiles
It refers to false teachers only
questions.correctAnswer: The enemy represents the devil sowing wickedness among believers
questions.explanation: Matthew 13:39 clarifies that the enemy is the devil, who sows tares (evil) among the wheat (believers). This depicts the ongoing spiritual conflict between good and evil in the world (Ephesians 6:12; 1 Peter 5:8; John 10:10; Revelation 12:9).

questions.question: What does the harvest represent in the parable of the tares according to Matthew 13?
options: The end of the world when angels separate the wicked from the righteous
The gathering of the Jewish people
The destruction of the temple
The establishment of the church
questions.correctAnswer: The end of the world when angels separate the wicked from the righteous
questions.explanation: Matthew 13:39-40 states that the harvest is the end of the world, when angels will gather the wicked to be burned and collect the righteous, emphasizing final judgment (Daniel 12:2; Matthew 25:31-46; Revelation 20:11-15; 2 Thessalonians 1:7-9).

questions.question: What does Jesus say about the kingdom of heaven in the parable of the mustard seed?
options: It starts small but grows into something great and sheltering
It is immediately powerful and visible
It is hidden and never grows
It is only for the Jews
questions.correctAnswer: It starts small but grows into something great and sheltering
questions.explanation: Matthew 13:31-32 describes the mustard seed as the smallest seed that grows into the greatest herb, becoming a tree that shelters birds. This illustrates the kingdom’s humble beginnings and expansive growth (Luke 13:18-19; Daniel 4:12; Ezekiel 17:23; Revelation 7:17).

questions.question: In Matthew 13, what does the leaven represent in the parable of the leaven?
options: The pervasive and transformative power of the kingdom of heaven
Sin that corrupts the world
The law of Moses
False doctrine
questions.correctAnswer: The pervasive and transformative power of the kingdom of heaven
questions.explanation: Matthew 13:33 compares the kingdom of heaven to leaven hidden in meal, which permeates the whole. This signifies the kingdom’s hidden but powerful influence transforming all it touches (1 Corinthians 5:6-8; Luke 13:20-21; Galatians 5:22-23; Romans 12:2).

questions.question: According to Matthew 13, what happens to the wicked at the end of the world?
options: They are cast into the furnace of fire with wailing and gnashing of teeth
They are forgiven and welcomed into the kingdom
They become angels
They are transformed into righteous people
questions.correctAnswer: They are cast into the furnace of fire with wailing and gnashing of teeth
questions.explanation: Matthew 13:42 and 13:50 describe the fate of the wicked at the end of the world as being cast into eternal fire with weeping and gnashing of teeth, emphasizing eternal judgment (Revelation 20:14-15; Matthew 25:41; Daniel 12:2; 2 Thessalonians 1:9).

questions.question: What is the meaning of the 'treasure hidden in a field' in Matthew 13?
options: The inestimable value of the kingdom of heaven
A secret place of refuge
A lost inheritance
A parable about wealth only
questions.correctAnswer: The inestimable value of the kingdom of heaven
questions.explanation: Matthew 13:44 portrays the kingdom of heaven like treasure hidden in a field, which a man sells all he has to buy. This illustrates the incomparable worth of the kingdom, calling for total commitment (Psalm 119:72; Philippians 3:8; Isaiah 55:1-3; Luke 14:33).

questions.question: In the parable of the pearl of great price, what action does the merchant take upon finding the pearl?
options: He sells all he has and buys it
He hides it for safekeeping
He discards it as worthless
He gives it to his friends
questions.correctAnswer: He sells all he has and buys it
questions.explanation: Matthew 13:46 tells how the merchant, upon finding a pearl of great price, sells all to buy it. This signifies the supreme value of the kingdom of heaven, demanding sacrifice and total surrender (Luke 18:29-30; Philippians 3:7-9; Romans 12:1; Mark 10:21).

questions.question: What does the kingdom of heaven likened to a net in Matthew 13 represent?
options: The gathering of all people at the end of the age for judgment
A fishing expedition by the disciples
An exclusive group of believers
A temporary church assembly
questions.correctAnswer: The gathering of all people at the end of the age for judgment
questions.explanation: Matthew 13:47-49 compares the kingdom to a net gathering all kinds of fish, then sorting the good from the bad at the shore, symbolizing the final judgment gathering all humanity (Revelation 20:12-15; Matthew 25:31-46; Daniel 7:9-10; John 5:28-29).

questions.question: In Matthew 13, what is the reason Jesus did not perform many mighty works in His own country?
options: Because of their unbelief
Because He was rejected by the religious leaders
Because He was too busy teaching elsewhere
Because He was physically weak
questions.correctAnswer: Because of their unbelief
questions.explanation: Matthew 13:58 states that Jesus did not perform many miracles in His hometown due to their unbelief, highlighting how faith is necessary for receiving God's works (John 4:48; Mark 6:5-6; Hebrews 11:6; Romans 1:17).

questions.question: How does Matthew 13 describe the heart of those who hear but do not understand the word of the kingdom?
options: Their hearts are hardened and their eyes and ears closed
They have a heart open to receive the truth
Their hearts are full of joy and peace
Their hearts are humble and teachable
questions.correctAnswer: Their hearts are hardened and their eyes and ears closed
questions.explanation: Matthew 13:15 describes people's hearts as waxed gross, ears dull, and eyes closed to prevent understanding and conversion, fulfilling Isaiah’s prophecy about spiritual blindness (Isaiah 6:9-10; 2 Corinthians 3:14-16; Romans 1:21-22; John 12:40).

questions.question: What does Jesus say about those who have ears to hear in Matthew 13?
options: Let them hear and understand the parables
They will be confused by the parables
They will reject the teachings
They should ask for explanations only
questions.correctAnswer: Let them hear and understand the parables
questions.explanation: Matthew 13:9 and 13:43 conclude several parables with 'Who hath ears to hear, let him hear,' calling for attentive and receptive hearing, emphasizing spiritual discernment (Proverbs 4:20-23; Ezekiel 3:10; Luke 8:8; Revelation 2:7).

questions.question: What does Jesus mean by 'every scribe instructed unto the kingdom of heaven is like a householder' in Matthew 13?
options: They bring forth new and old teachings from God's treasure
They must focus only on old teachings
They should reject new insights
They are responsible for building physical houses
questions.correctAnswer: They bring forth new and old teachings from God's treasure
questions.explanation: Matthew 13:52 compares scribes instructed in the kingdom to householders who bring out treasures new and old, showing the continuity and development of God's revelation (Deuteronomy 29:29; Psalm 119:160; John 16:12-13; 2 Timothy 3:16).
